entry.title: Stablecoins Analysis
entry.content:
Can we trust the peg?

The term “stablecoin” refers to coins whose value was tied to another asset before they were released.

Stablecoins do not experience the same level of volatility as bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies.

The rationale for this is that it fixes the exchange rate on “real” money or precious metals.

What Makes Stablecoins Different From Other Cryptocurrencies?

The fundamental distinction between stablecoins and other cryptocurrencies is that, as the name implies, stablecoins are concerned with price stability.

One of the biggest problems discouraging investors from investing in cryptocurrencies is the fluctuating price.

The Different Kinds of Stablecoins

Most people think about Tether when they think of Stablecoin (USDT).
As a result, they consider the stablecoin to be an electronic money backed 1:1 by the dollar.
Stablecoins, on the other hand, have a broader definition.
The following are the four categories of stablecoins:

  • Fiat-Collateralized

  • Commodity-Collateralized

  • Crypto-Collateralized

  • Non-Collateralized

Fiat-Collateralized

In the cryptocurrency market, this is the most frequent sort of stablecoin.

Fiat-collateralized stablecoins, as their name implies, are backed 1:1 by fiat currencies such as the US dollar (USD), euro (EUR), or yen (JPY) (JPY).

A fixed equivalent between fiat currency and fixed currencies is established prior to circulation.

Stablecoins backed by fiat are minted in a centralized manner.
It means that they are launched and even controlled by a single entity.
A firm, a bank, or even the government are examples of such organizations.

This central organization must keep the same quantity of fiat money on hand as the stablecoins it sells to the market.

  • Tether (USDT) is the most well-known fiat-backed stablecoin, if not all stablecoins.

Tether Limited’s cryptocurrency is the undisputed leader among fiat-backed stablecoins.

Aside from Tether, fiat-based stable coins include :

  • TrueUSD (TUSD)
  • EURO Stasis (EURS)
  • Brazilian Digital Token (BRZ).

This category includes the world’s most valued stablecoins, such as the Gemini Dollar (GUSD), named after the Winklevoss brothers, and the Ethereum-based USDC.

Commodity-Collateralized

While most stablecoins are backed by actual money, there is another form of stablecoin that is backed by a commodity.

Commodity-backed stablecoins are what they’re called.

This commodity might be anything from oil to gas to precious metals like gold to real estate.

Stablecoins have the same value as the underlying assets.

The following are some of the most well-known stablecoins in this category:

  • DigixDAO (DGX) is a stablecoin that has been around for a long time.
    The value of the DGX is linked to gold.
    One token is equal to 0.1 gram of gold.
    To ensure its transparency, the money is reviewed every three months.
  • SwissRealCoin is a security token that is backed by a Swiss Commercial Real Estate portfolio.
  • Tiberius Coin (TCX) is backed by seven precious and basic metals that are commonly used in the technology sector.
  • PAX Gold (PAGX) is another stablecoin whose value is tied to the price of gold.
  • Petro (PTR) is the Venezuelan government’s official cryptocurrency, backed by oil barrels.

Crypto-Collateralized

This form of stablecoin has a decentralized structure, unlike previous stablecoins.
Other cryptocurrencies back them up.

MakerDAO’s DAI is the most widely used crypto-collateralized stablecoin.

Unlike previous forms of collateral, collateral is kept on Blockchain instantaneously and issued using smart contracts.
This ensures that processes are safe and transparent.
Users can, for example, use a portion of their Ethereum holdings as collateral to borrow DAI, which is backed by the US dollar.

Non-Collateralized

Non-collateralized stablecoins are the fourth and most recent type of stablecoin.

They are not backed by anything and are managed by a supply-demand elasticity mechanism based on an algorithm.

Robert Sams, who originated this concept in 2014, is known as Seigniorage shares.

Smart contracts are used to manage seigniorage shares.

The algorithm will increase the overall supply when the price of a Stablecoin becomes too high owing to increased demand, and decrease the supply when the price falls.

Stablecoins in this category include:

  • Carbon
  • Steem Dollar
  • Bitpay Official
  • Nubits.

Erik Voorhees - ShapeShift CEO

“ Stablecoins are important in the same way that a bridge is important. You may not care much about the bridge, but without it, the beautiful land beyond is much harder to get to.”

entry.title: The Coinbase Effect
entry.content:
Investigating the “Coinbase Effect”

Analyzing the impact of digital token listings on one of the most well-known cryptocurrency exchanges

When new listings are announced, this well-known phenomenon in the cryptoworld investigates and quantifies the positive effects on digital asset values.

Let’s start from the beginning for those who are unfamiliar with the crypto realm.

Coinbase is the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the United States, and many people consider it to be the best way to get started with cryptocurrencies.

Its prospects have improved even more as a result of the boom over the last 12 months.

So much so that on April 14, the crypto exchange became public under the ticker ‘COIN.’

The ‘Coinbase effect’ is explained as follows: When a cryptocurrency is listed on a popular exchange, it immediately obtains exposure to a new set of market players and increases in value.

The effect has previously been thoroughly researched, with Coinbase serving as the primary exchange.

However, this study expands on past research by include five more crypto exchanges to examine what kind of influence identical listings on other platforms have.

Data from six centralized cryptocurrencies are listed below:

1. Coinbase(28 listings)

2. Binance (22 listings)

3. FTX (19 listings)

4. Gemini (19 listings)

5. Kraken (11 listings)

6. OKEx (14 listings)

To capture the effect, the researchers looked at the distribution of cumulative returns five days following the token listing as a preliminary estimate.

Coinbase listings, as expected, provided the highest average return of 91 percent, but they also had the biggest distribution, with returns ranging from -32 percent to 645 percent.

When compared to other exchanges, Coinbase listings result in larger returns, as evidenced by the data above.

The Coinbase dataset did, however, contain some outliers, as shown in the second figure on the right, which highlights six listings that saw outsized rises.

The following were among them:

  • District0x — (645%)
  • Civic — (492%)
  • Band protocol — (234%)
  • The Graph — (169%)
  • Numeraire — (167%)
  • Skale network — (135%)

According to the data, exchange listings, particularly Coinbase, almost always result in an increase in asset returns.
However, the overall market situation at the time of listing is a crucial component to consider when tabulating such findings.

entry.title: Proof of Capacity Consensus
entry.content:
The Proof of Capacity (PoC) concept

Proof of capacity (PoC) is a consensus mechanism method used in blockchains that allows mining devices in the network to decide mining rights and validate transactions using their available hard drive space.

This is in contrast to using the processing power of the mining device (as in the proof of work method) or the miner’s cryptocurrency stake (as in the proof of stake algorithm).

What is Proof of Burn?

Proof of capacity is one of many alternatives to the problems of high energy consumption in Proof of Work (PoW) systems and tokens hoarding in Proof of Stake (PoS) systems.

Proof of capacity allows mining devices on the blockchain network, also known as nodes, to mine available cryptocurrencies using free space on their hard drives.

PoC works by storing a list of possible solutions on the mining device’s hard drive even before the mining activity begins, rather than repeatedly changing the numbers in the block header and hashing for the solution value as in a PoW system.

The more possible solution values a miner can store on his hard drive, the more chances he has to match the required hash value from his list, resulting in a higher chance of winning the mining reward.

To use an analogy, if lottery prizes are determined by matching the most numbers on the winning ticket, a player with a longer list of potential solutions will have a better chance of winning.

Furthermore, the player is allowed to use the lottery ticket block numbers over and over again.

How Plotting and Mining works?

Plotting and mining are two steps in the proof-of-capacity protocol.

First, the hard drive is plotted: a list of all potential nonce values is constructed by hashing data, including a miner’s account, over and over again.

Each nonce is made up of 8192 hashes, numbered from 0 to 8191.

All of the hashes are coupled into “scoops,” which are groups of two neighboring hashes.

For example, hash 0 and 1 equals scoop 0, hash 2 and 3 equals hash 1, and so on.

The second phase is the actual mining, which entails calculating a scoop number by a miner.

For example, if a miner starts mining and generates scoop number 38, the miner would then go to nonce 1’s scoop number 38 and utilize the data from that scoop to calculate a deadline value.

For each nonce stored on the miner’s hard drive, the process is repeated to calculate the deadline.

The miner chooses the one with the shortest deadline after calculating all of the deadlines.

Before a miner is authorized to produce a new block, a deadline represents the amount of time in seconds that has passed since the last block was forged.

The miner can fabricate a block and claim the block reward if no one else has done so inside this time frame.

For example, if miner X sets a minimum deadline of 36 seconds and no other miners can forge the block within that time, X will be guaranteed the opportunity to forge the next block and be rewarded.

entry.title: Namecoin
entry.content:
Namecoin origins

Namecoin is a cryptocurrency that was created as a derivative of the Bitcoin software.
Namecoin is based on the Bitcoin technology, with additional features added on top.
Namecoin follows Bitcoin’s proof-of-work (PoW) consensus algorithm.
The two currencies are practically equivalent in terms of value.

Namecoin was created with the goal of creating a decentralized domain name system (DNS).
The Domain Name System (DNS) converts human-readable domain names (such as www.misu.one) to machine-readable IP addresses (for example, 000.0.0.00).
DNS is the system that connects domain names to numerical IP addresses all around the world.
The goal of decentralizing this system was to eliminate Internet censorship and improve Internet security and privacy.
Namecoin is “an experimental open-source solution that increases the decentralization, security, censorship resistance, privacy, and speed of some components of the Internet infrastructure, such as DNS and identities,” according to its creators.

What Namecoin Does?

Many Namecoin proponents feel that a decentralized DNS system is essential for long-term Internet privacy and censorship reduction.

While most people are unlikely to need a.bit website or related service, Namecoin could give certain people the tools they need to connect to an Internet free of censorship and central control.

Despite the fact that we type text-based website addresses into Internet browsers, the Internet is actually built on numerical addresses known as IP addresses.

The DNS was established to make Internet navigation easier because a large string of numbers is difficult to remember.

The Domain Name System (DNS) is the Internet’s address book.

A DNS server is called every time you enter in a website address.

The DNS server determines the IP address of the Internet destination server before retrieving the data for that web page.

The top-level domain (.com) is the last part of a website’s domain (TLD).

A central authority is in charge of all TLDs.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, for example, manages the top-level domain.com (ICANN).

When a specific complaint about a webpage develops, the TLD’s central authority has final say over how the complaint is resolved.

Lawyers or copyright proprietors will correspond with the central authority in the vast majority of real-world issues.

Those concerned about censorship, on the other hand, may find the existence of any central authority with the authority to issue directives troublesome.

TLDs that are not owned by anyone can now exist thanks to the introduction of a decentralized DNS system.

A peer-to-peer system also serves as the querying system for a decentralized DNS.

Volunteers manage the customized DNS server software in a peer-to-peer system, and no central authority can meddle in the TLD’s functioning.

entry.title: Proof of Assignment Consensus
entry.content:
The Proof of Assignment (PoA) concept

Proof of Assignment (PoA)’s operating method enables basic, low-capacity mining operations to be performed using everyday Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

In comparison to its predecessors, Proof of Assignment (PoA) is a cryptographic consensus process that uses less power and can run on relatively low-end hardware.
Traditional consensus methods like as Proof of Work (PoW) and Proof of Stake (PoS) appear to waste more energy and require significantly more computer power and memory to function, according to PoA.

What is Proof of Assignment?

A consensus mechanism is a fault-tolerant technique used in distributed computer networks and blockchain applications to obtain the required agreement on a single data value or network state among decentralized processes or multi-agent systems, such as cryptocurrency.

It’s also handy for keeping track of and coordinating a group of distributed connected devices, such as with the Internet of Things.

Major household appliances, such as vacuum cleaners, washing machines, and refrigerators, as well as other commonly used consumer electronics, such as smartwatches and printers, now include advanced microprocessors, microcontrollers, and memory modules capable of connecting to the internet and each other—the IoT’s basic concept.

It enables these devices to capture, process, and exchange data with other systems and networks in real time.

IoT-compatible gadgets with integrated computing capacity can be used for bitcoin mining.

Mining is a computer-based mathematical activity that allows new crypto currencies to be created and blockchain transactions to be verified.

However, because these devices’ memory and processing power are restricted, their contribution to mining is minimal.

This type of “lightweight” mining is made possible by the PoA algorithm’s functioning mechanism.

Benefits

PoA is said to have a bunch of new advantages.
To begin with, household gadgets can be used to contribute to mining, providing a viable answer to the scalability and transaction processing delays that today’s popular cryptocurrency networks suffer.

Additionally, device owners can set a timetable for when their gadgets contribute to mining when they are idle.

They may also willingly share or sell the data created and processed by their gadgets in order to earn crypto coins, as this data can be helpful to a wide range of entities involved in market research, consumer patterns research, and city planning.

entry.title: Mimblewimble
entry.content:
Mimblewimble is a confidential transactions blockchain protocol.

It allows for a considerably simpler blockchain in which all spent transactions can be cut off.

Essentially, an Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) can be considered public key and the differential between outputs, inputs and transaction fees for a valid confidential transaction has to be 0.

A prover who builds a confidential transaction can thus sign the transaction with the public key difference between the outputs and inputs.

This allows that new nodes can validate the whole blockchain efficiently without having to download any previous and used transactions.

The blockchain consists only of blockheaders, remaining UTXO outputs and a non-removable kernel of transactions.

The blockchain is composed of blockheaders.

Mimblewimble also allows the aggregation of transactions before the blockchain is committed.

Although there are strong guarantees of confidence, even in Mimblewimble, all commitments which are unique can still be registered for each transaction received and traced, which entries are transformed into which outputs and therefore the transaction graph efficiently reconstructed.

This can be done easily by adding a network node for monitoring all transactions through the network.

This does not, of course, constitute a significant infringement of privacy since although UTXO has been declared anonymous, the entire history of this user does not become declared anonymous (unlike in Bitcoin).

Mimblewimble basics

  1. No addresses available.

  2. No amounts are available.

  3. 2 transactions can be merged into one block, one spending another in one block, and all intermediary details deleted.

How are we doing that?

A encryption sounds great, but what it means is, “I’m proving I knew before I made it public because I can’t reverse the hash to reveal myself.”

In addition, commitments (for example) are made to demonstrate public forecasts even beyond cryptocurrencies, such as John Galt’s public forecast of the development of projects in 2018 on 1 January.

In 2019, John can reveal his list and people can easily check to see if his list (in plain text in English) corresponds to the previous year.

entry.title: Bulletproofs
entry.content:
Bulletproofs are among the distinct Zero-knowledge Proof systems

Like the Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive ARguments of Knowledge (zk-SNARK), the Zero Knowledge Prover and Verifier for Boolean Circuits (ZKBoo) and the Succinct Transparent ARgument of Knowledge (STARK).

Zero-knowledge proofs are designed to allow a prover to indirectly ensure that a statement is true without any information after the statement has been verified.

In order to demonstrate that a number is found to be used to resolve a cryptographic puzzle and that the hash value is adjusted without the disclosure of the hash value.

The Bulletproofs Technology is a non-interactive zero-knowledge (NIZK) protocol with very short proofs for general arithmetic circuitry (Arguments of Knowledge Systems).

They rely on the assumption of Discrete Logarithm (DL) and are interactive with the Fiat-Shamir Heuristic.

The name “Bulletproof” came from a nontechnical summary by one of the original authors of the scheme: “Short like the bullet with security assumptions that prove to be ballots.”

Bulletproofs is essentially its algorithm for internal products, originally presented by Groth and further refined by Bootle et la.

Later development provided evidence (knowledge argument) for two independent (not related) binding vector Pedersen Commitments, which met the relationship between the product and product.

Bulletproofs build upon these techniques, which provide no-knowledge, communication effective evidence, but replace the internal product argument with an additional one, reducing communication overall by three.

Bulletproofs are also deployed in a Multi-Party Computing (MPC) protocol that aggregates distributed evidence of several provers with secret committed values into a single proof before the challenge of Fiat Shamir is determined and transmitted to the verifier and minimizes communication rounds.

Secret values committed will remain secret.

entry.title: Proof of Burn Consensus
entry.content:
The Proof of Burn (PoB) concept

Proof of burn is one of the various consensus mechanism methods used by a blockchain network to ensure that all participating nodes agree on the blockchain network’s real and valid state.

This algorithm is in place to prevent any cryptocurrency coin from being double-spent.

Proof of burn is based on the idea of miners “burning” the coins that provide them mining rights.

The blockchain is a cryptocurrency’s core database.

It stores all transaction-related information in blocks, which serve as the blockchain’s data storage units.

Only when all of the blockchain nodes agree on a set of transactions that they consider valid, a block is recorded.

Because of the blockchain network’s independent and decentralized character, an automated system is essential to ensure that all participating nodes agree on only acceptable transactions.

Consensus-mechanism algorithms handle this critical duty.

What is Proof of Burn?

Proof of burn (POB) is an alternative consensus algorithm that tries to address the high energy consumption issue of a POW system.

POB is often called a POW system without energy waste. It operates on the principle of allowing miners to “burn” virtual currency tokens. They are then granted the right to write blocks in proportion to the coins burnt.

Iain Stewart, the creator of the POB algorithm, compares burned coins to mining rigs to describe the method.

In this example, a miner uses his or her money to purchase a virtual mining setup that allows them to mine blocks.

The miner’s virtual mining “rig” will grow in size as more coins are burned.

The POB algorithm’s creator, Iain Stewart, compares burned coins to mining rigs to describe the algorithm.

A miner burns his coins to buy a virtual mining setup that allows them to mine blocks in this analogy.

The miner’s virtual mining “rig” will grow in size as the miner burns more money.

You can use the network to send transactions that will burn your own cryptocurrency tokens.

Other participants can mine/burn on top of your block, and you can add other participants’ transactions to your block as well.

Essentially, all of this coin-burning activity maintains the network nimble, and players are rewarded for their efforts (both their own and others’ coins).

entry.title: ZK-Proof
entry.content:
Verifying the validity of a secret without disclosing the secret

Have you ever tried to prove to someone that you know a secret without really exposing the secret?

It may appear tough to persuade people that you have precise expertise without revealing what that knowledge is.

This is, however, the precise circumstance for many digital and online procedures in which the system must verify that particular information is valid or genuine without exposing it.

This is, however, the perfect circumstance for many digital and online procedures in which the system must verify that particular information is genuine or truthful without exposing potentially sensitive stuff (such as personal data).

This is where zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) come into play.

A ZKP is a cryptographic protocol between a prover we may name Peggy and a Victor verifier, in which the former attempts to convince the latter of the truth without disclosing information other than the veracity of the assertion.

ZKP’s idea is nicely stated in the post How to explain zero-knowledge protocols to your children.

The narrative is about a magical cave where entry divides into two dark twisting passages: one on the left and one on the right.

Deeper down the cave, apparently, both pathways migrate backwards, almost connecting to one another, but remain divided by a wall.

Therefore, if you opt to go in one route, you have to go out of the cave and turn back.

The cave still has a secret. The wall separating the tunnels opens and is connecting with a whispering of the magic words “open sesame.”

Peggy says Victor understands the key words that the wall is opening, but he wants her to show that this is real.

To achieve this, Victor presents himself with a challenge: at the entrance of the cave, he waits and asks Peggy to enter the cave by using the left route and to come out by using the right pass.

It’s only conceivable if Péggy knows the magic words thus if she finishes the task successfully, Victor is persuaded that despite the fact that none of them tells the other magic words, Peggy knows the magical words.

A zero-knowledge evidence must thus fulfill the following characteristics:

  1. Completeness: The prover can convince the verifier that the assertion is true if the statement is true.

  2. Soundness: If the declaration is incorrect, the prover cannot persuade the proof that the declaration is true.

  3. Zero-Knowledge: if the declaration is true, the verification does not learn any more than the declaration is true.

How are zero-knowledge proofs utilized in online voting?

Zero-knowledge is a significant factor when discussing about online voting systems regarding verifiability or vote correctness (to learn more about security requirements for online voting, check out this article).

Rightness of vote

Let’s conceive of a referendum in which a list of questions is submitted to the voters and they must respond to each question whether or not.

The vote system (a mobile phone, a laptop, etc.) recognizes the response yes as 1 and the reply negative as 0. To encrypt these responses,
In such a system, it is necessary to show that the encrypted value is actually one or one, so that the malicious voter cannot vote on a single issue more than once; e.g., encryption of the option by number 3.

To achieve thus, the system produces a zero-knowledge proof that the encrypted value is a

Checking Universal

A method of online voting should produce proof for the universal verificability that anybody has been able to verify that the results of the elections were computed from votes by qualified voters, and that those votes were not altered during the counting process.

Usually, this verification is supplied through certificates.

Regardless of the technique of anonymization employed throughout the counting process, votes should be decrypted, such as mixing or homomorphic counting.

Decryption is a vulnerable procedure which requires to carry out a private key.

To safeguard the privacy of each voter, this key must be secured.

If we want to verify that the decryption process has been carried out correctly without any votes being modified, added or deleted, zero-knowledge proofs are generated to show that the decrypted votes are those which have been encrypted and that no information is being drawn from the private election key and the contents of every ballot.

Zero-Knowledge proof is only one of several security procedures that can be used during elections online and helps in particular to provide verifiability and transparency while still safeguarding the privacy of voters and integrity overall in the elections.

entry.title: Proof of Stake Consensus
entry.content:
The Proof of Stake (PoS) concept

According to the Proof of Stake (PoS) idea, a person’s ability to mine or validate block transactions is proportional to the number of coins they own.
This means that the more coins a miner owns, the greater their mining power.

The proof of stake concept was developed as an alternative to the “proof of work (PoW)” concept, in order to address the latter’s fundamental flaws.

The proof of stake idea is currently exclusively used by altcoins.

When a transaction is started, the data is put into a block, which is subsequently duplicated among several computers or network nodes.

The nodes are the blockchain’s administrative body, and they verify the authenticity of each block’s transactions.

In 2015, one Bitcoin transaction was predicted to consume enough electricity to power 1.57 American households for one day.

That figure has only risen since then.

Proof of Stake’s Impact on Mining

Bitcoin consumes around 119.87 terawatt-hours every year, according to the University of Cambridge’s Bitcoin Electricity Consumption Index, which is more than the United Arab Emirates and the Netherlands utilize annually.

Miners typically sell their awarded coins for fiat money to cover their electricity bills, causing the cryptocurrency’s price to fall.

Proof of stake (PoS) attempts to overcome this problem by tying mining power to the number of coins a miner owns.

Instead of wasting energy solving PoW problems, a PoS miner is constrained to mining a percentage of transactions according to their ownership share.

A miner who owns 3% of the coins available, for example, can theoretically only mine 3% of the blocks.

entry.title: Proof of Work Consensus
entry.content:
The Proof of Work (PoW) Concept

Proof of work (PoW) refers to a system that necessitates a considerable but manageable amount of effort in order to discourage frivolous or malicious uses of computing power, such as sending spam emails or launching denial-of-service attacks.

Hal Finney applied the notion to protecting digital money in 2004 using the SHA-256 hashing technique and the concept of “reusable proof of work.”

Bitcoin was the first widely used application of Finney’s PoW concept after its release in 2009. (Finney was also the recipient of the first bitcoin transaction).

Many other cryptocurrencies are based on proof of work, which allows for secure, decentralized consensus.

This discussion will concentrate on how proof of work works in the bitcoin network.
Bitcoin is a digital money that is supported by a “blockchain,” which is a type of distributed ledger.

This ledger keeps track of all bitcoin transactions and organizes them into “blocks” so that no user may spend the same amount of bitcoin twice.

The ledger is public, or “distributed,” to avoid manipulation; an altered version would be rapidly rejected by other users.

In practice, users identify tampering using hashes, which are long strings of numbers that act as proof of work.

When you run a set of data through a hash function (SHA-256 is used in Bitcoin), it will only ever produce one hash.

However, due to the “avalanche effect,” even little changes to any part of the original data will result in a hash that is completely unrecognizable.

The hash created by a given function will be the same length regardless of the size of the underlying data set.

The hash function is a one-way function: it can only be used to verify that the data that created the hash matches the original data.

For a modern computer, generating any hash for a set of bitcoin transactions would be cheap, thus the bitcoin network sets a particular level of “difficulty” to transform the process into “work.”

This option is changed such that a new block is “mined” – that is, added to the blockchain by creating a valid hash – every 10 minutes or so.

The complexity of a hash is determined by its “target”: the lower the target, the narrower the set of valid hashes and the more difficult it is to construct one.

In practice, this means a hash with a long string of zeros at the beginning.

More you know

Proof of work was first offered as a response to the rising problem of spam email.

entry.title: Online voting security
entry.content:
Online voting safety technique

Ways to improve and strengthen online voting security

In order to achieve the same or greater security as traditional paper voting, online voting must fulfill a number of conditions.

The four major categories may arrange these requirements: authentication, integrity, privacy and verification.

Authentification

Authentication needs voters to be recognized in such a way as to differentiate them unambiguously from others.

Authentication may be achieved through many techniques, such as: the secure delivery of pairs of name and password for voters, pre-existing citizen credentials, such as those that are used in government online portals, or electronic ID cards, such as National IDs.

Such techniques can also be coupled with other authentication elements such as secondary device (for example, SMS code provided to the mobile device) or biometric authentication (fingerprints or face scans).

The e-voting system may check the eligibility of the voter by means of various authentication techniques and will provide access only for persons who have the right to vote.

Integrity

Integrity indicates that voting method or any improper influence shall not impact the intention of an elector.

Integrity is guaranteed at several levels and at different times throughout the election in the online voting method.

Each ballot is first signed digitally with a key that is unique to every voter throughout the voting time, guaranteeing that the vote is not modified by any other voters but themselves.

Later on, when the voting is encrypted and anonymized, digital signatures are employed to safeguard intermediate data that is transferred during the screening process and mathematical evidence is also utilized to guarantee the integrity of processes themselves, depending on the kind of election.

Sensitive and manipulative information, such as configuration of election files, is also digitally signed to avoid tampering.

Privacy

Privacy involves keeping secret every vote and preserving the anonymity of voters.
At each point of the voting process, the electronic voting system must ensure that the secrecy of the vote is preserved, that the vote is secret and its content is not exposed.

This is done by encrypting the votes right before transmission on the voters’ device so that contents cannot be read until anonymous ballot is decrypted by the electoral board at the end of the election.

Every connection between an unsealed vote and the elector who casts it is based upon the anonymity of voters.

In this respect, methods like mixing, which corresponds to the mixing or homomorphic tallying of votes without decrypting outcomes, are utilized.

Verification

Verification is an asset that provides for accuracy checking in a number of the operations of the online voting system.

There are typically 3 forms of verification: cast-as-means, cast-as-cast and counted-as-written.

The first two are procedures for individual verification, since they relate to each elector and to the votes that they cast.

The latter is known as universal verification since anybody having the system data may check it.

Although many of these safety functions are truly complicated and advanced, it does not mean that an online voting system may be used.

Where practicable, each qualified provider should implement and automatically implement these steps to streamline the entire process, both for electoral organisers and voters.

They should also provide the support essential for the smooth and reliable conduct of the elections.
